ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Anthropological approach to fat and obesity, biosocial model of fat, developmental perspectives, what is a diet, food deserts, body norms and image
I learned so much in this class. Everything from adiposity, body image, different diets, and why weight isn't just about counting calories.
I learned a lot about how fatness is viewed in society, and I feel that this course does a good job of incorporating multiple perspectives/approaches!

This course provides you with a nuanced, intersectional understanding of fatness, obesity, and health. You will leave the course with a much more critical lens of conventional discourses and representations of fat and develop a vocabulary for thinking beyond it.
I learned about fat.

I learned about the role adipose tissue plays in keeping us alive. The intricacies of fat and its evolutionary and genetic origins. Gave me a whole new perspective on fat and positive outlook on my own body.
I learned about fat from a variety of different perspectives: biological, evolutionary, social, cultural, developmental etc.
I learned a lot of different perspectives on the issues related to course material.

I analyzed fat from diverse disciplines, including biology, public health/epidemiology, food studies, critical indigenous studies, economics, and development. 

Intellectually, I take away so much about the obesity research complex. I learned about the flaws of the medical system in treating overweight patients, the racial capitalism that underlies it, and the biases that medical practitioners carry that perpetuate obesity. Through insightful guest speaker, I realized that you can be overweight and healthy! 

Personally, I also developed a healthier respect for fatone of the most underlooked organs in the body.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The leminar format

Strengths: the content was really interesting and I liked how many different topics we covered
Weaknesses: sometimes it felt like the professors would assume that everyone had the same level of knowledge and experience regarding anthropology, so it was difficult to understand some concepts as someone who had no experience with the field of study, the class felt too big to really make any contributions of value
There are no weaknesses. Claudia was amazing!
I like the combined lecture and discussion format.

Strengths: engages a range of disciplines + lenses through our readings, lectures, conversations, guest speakers, etc, giving a well-rounded, nuanced presentation of fat and obesity.

Weaknesses: Some of the lectures could have been more engaging or interactive, particularly those in the beginning providing foundational biological knowledge about fat.
Strength is the material. Weakness is the sometimes too loose structure of classes and assignments.

Strengths: Professors are fantastic. Very engaging. Great range of projects, readings and lecture topics. Very well structured. 

Weakness: None. Great class!
Great class! No weaknesses.
I loved the way this "leminar" course was taught and I thought that it was interesting to hear about. I wished that the course felt more open to other opinions and less similar opinions.

Strengths:
 - The assignments and projects, though frequent, encourage students to think critically rather than just rinse and repeat knowledge from class
 - The loose deadlines, but firm deadline in the middle, gave students healthy wiggle room
 - Guest speakers enriched the syllabus. One piece of feedback is to thoroughly contextualize the speaker before they present to the class.
 Weaknesses:
 - More delineated times for questions, because I often felt that they bled into the lecture a lot and sometimes only served the speaker given the very accessible nature of fat

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I learned so many different perspectives on fat

I would recommend this course, but I think what you get out of the course really depends on what you put in. The content and projects are interesting but if you do not do the readings or work to engage with the content, it can feel like you're just going through the motions and I don't think it will be worth it to take the class. The class is a leminar format and quite large for a class of this nature, so sometimes it can feel that your contributions or ideas were not really valued or heard because the professors are trying to get to everyone.
Yes. Interesting topics and good professors.

I would recommend this course to any and all Yale students! We had a great breadth of majors and majors, and you do not need a scientific background to take it. It is very accessible to a range of disciplines, as it deals with broad societal issues of fatphobia and human health that involve all of us.
Yes, Claudia is an angel.
Yes 100%. Very transformative course for me.
Yes! Professor Valeggia, Kat, and the rest of the teaching team are super helpful and you learn a lot about adiposity.
Yes I have already recommended it to other students because I loved the content.
I HIGHLY recommend this course to anyone. No reservations.
